subject: Art & Design
title: Italian Neorealism: Cinema of the Streets
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Italian Neorealism: Cinema of the Streets.

hook.text: A man and his son search Rome for a stolen bicycle. It's heartbreaking, unglamorous, and entirely real.

buildup.text: Italian Neorealism (1940s-50s) rejected studio sets for real locations and non-professional actors.

discovery.text: Born from post-war poverty, filmmakers couldn't afford studios. Limitation became artistic philosophy.

twist.text: Hollywood told fantasy. Neorealism showed workers, poverty, and daily survival. It shocked global audiences.

climax.text: De Sica, Rossellini, and Visconti inspired every independent film movement that followed.

punchline.text: Neorealism proved that reality is more dramatic than fiction.

quiz.question: What defined Italian Neorealism?
options: Real locations, non-professional actors, and stories of ordinary life
Elaborate studio sets and professional actors
Science fiction themes and special effects
